awd_titl_txt: LTREB Renewal: Trajectory for the Recovery of Stream Ecosystem Structure and Function during Reforestation
awd_abstract_narration:
Reforestation of riparian areas is widely considered a best management practice for   restoring and improving water and habitat quality of streams and rivers throughout the United States.  Millions of dollars are invested in riparian forest restoration each year by state, federal, and private agencies and institutions.  However, little is known about how long it takes for the physical, chemical, and biological aspects of a stream ecosystem to be restored so that the ecosystem can once again provide the services that humans need (i.e. it is swimmable, fishable, drinkable).  Nor is there much known about the stages that the stream ecosystem passes through during that restoration process and the stream?s relative functionality at each stage. This project will document the time frames of various stages of stream ecosystem restoration, characterize the sequence of those changes through time, and reveal whether the trajectory of recovery of stream ecosystem structure (physical, chemical, biological) parallels that of ecosystem function (delivery of service to humans).  This information, in turn, will help provide the technical basis for better managing riparian corridors so that both the quantity and quality of fresh water for both humans and wildlife can be sustained at a high level for future generations.

The negative effects of eliminating riparian forest along stream ecosystems are well documented.  Yet, the science of stream ecosystem recovery to riparian forest restoration is weak at best.  This project quantifies the trajectory of stream ecosystem recovery in terms of its physical structure, flow of energy, cycling of nutrients, and the composition of biological communities following reforestation of meadows or pastures with native deciduous trees. As the planted forest grows and matures, research will focus on the time frames over which stream ecosystem variables change compared to reference- endpoints of a mature forested- and meadow stream reach. The project is interdisciplinary, and brings together research in fluvial geomorphology, hydrology, biogeochemistry, organic and isotope geochemistry, nutrient cycling, and community ecology of heterotrophic and autotrophic microorganisms, macroinvertebrates, and fishes to describe the trajectory of stream change as a forested riparian matures.  Key research questions include: the change over time and order of change of different biophysical variables, such as light, temperature, channel geomorphology, bed complexity and hyporheic zone exchange, to documenting the efficiency and magnitude of food-web processing of organic Carbon as organic inputs change during reforestation and the relationship between the level of ecosystem services such as Carbon and Nitrogen processing scale and the degree of stream ecosystem restoration.  The project includes several innovative approaches including large wood debris inventories and fate-tracking, hyporheic exchange studies, LIDAR earth/vegetation surveys, molecular fingerprint analysis of microbial communities, species level analysis of macroinvertebrate community structure, fish biomass and productivity measures, and stable isotope analysis of food and functional feeding animal groups. Ongoing and active outreach citizen based scientists, municipal employees and farmers by Stroud researchers will allow public participation using low cost, open source sensors deployed in the WCC LTREB for water quality parameters.

por.por_cntn:
Removal of riparian forest vegetation is one of the primary drivers of stream impairment, and the multi-billion dollar river restoration industry commonly includes riparian reforestation. The need for assessment and guidance of river restoration activities includes generating knowledge of key time scales for ecosystem restoration as this is fundamental to understanding and predicting the dynamics of ecosystem recovery. The research described here addresses questions concerning the temporal dynamics of stream ecosystems in response to reforestation.

Scientists from Stroud Water Research Center with expertise in geomorphology, geochemistry, ecosystem science, and microbial, macroinvertebrate and fish ecology are in the midst of a multi decade-long research plan to understand and document changes in the ecology of a section of White Clay Creek (WCC) in southeastern Pennsylvania during reforestation. Restoration in this study involves reforestation of streamside meadows or pastures with native deciduous trees, and is therefore a semi-passive restoration with no direct stream channel or riparian/floodplain interventions. As the planted forest matures, scientists consider the time frame over which physical, chemical, and biological components of stream ecosystems change.

Restoration of a 3rd order reach of WCC began in 1967, when the Stroud Center was established, on land adjacent to the stream that was used for livestock grazing. Restoration of a 2nd-order reach was initiated in 1999. In both cases, livestock were fenced out of the meadows adjacent to the stream, invasive plants were removed, and native tree seedlings were planted to reestablish a contiguous forest extending upstream to a border with a mature “Forest” reach (>80 yrs). For the 3rd-order site, a “Meadow” reach downstream of the “Reforested” reach has been maintained without trees. The research described here was initiated in 1998 to measure changes in stream ecosystem structure and function as the trees grow in the Reforested reach and to compare changes with long-established Forest and Meadow reaches.

Research results measure the physical, chemical, and biological responses of stream ecosystems to riparian reforestation. To date, this long-term study has documented physical changes (i.e., increased shading, decreased temperature, widening and slight aggrading of the channel) in the Reforested reach relative to the Forest reach. In contrast, the Forest reach has had a largely stable channel geometry (width, depth) with some minor lateral movement, and the channel in the Meadow reach remains more narrow and deep while rapidly migrating in the floodplain, with actively eroding, steep banks that slump into the channel and create temporary, small-scale grassy islands. Furthermore, it appears that where large wood debris (LWD) has entered the Reforested reach, channel widening and bar formation has accelerated, supporting the hypothesis that LWD accelerates channel recovery (re-widening to resemble the mature forest). The results from the two Reforested reaches show that dramatic changes in physical conditions such as shade, temperature, and channel and floodplain geomorphology occur within the first two decades of reforestation, but significant change can continue for decades after that.

Biological responses have also been observed in microbial and aquatic macroinvertebrate communities. As the streamside forest has grown in the Reforested reach, leaf litter input (and important food source for streams) has increased and is now more similar to the Forested reach than the Meadow reach. While the bacterial community structure on rock habitats (gravel, cobble) in the Reforested reach are still distinct from Meadow and Forest reaches, the bacterial communities in the Reforested reach are now more similar to the Forest reach than the Meadow reach. Bacterial communities associated with fine sediment deposits (sand, silt, clay) do not show as much change, but these substrates are subject to greater disturbance during frequent high-flow or flood events. Similarly, macroinvertebrate community structure is still significantly different between the 2nd-order Forest and Reforested stream reaches. However, a transition has started, and macroinvertebrate structure in the Reforested reach has become far more similar to the Forest reach. Even though the reforestation is 30 years older, increased similarity has also been observed for macroinvertebrates between Forest and Reforested sections of the 3rd-order stream.

To date, this study has measured significant ecological benefits from the simple reforestation of streamside habitats – shade increased, temperature decreased, channel geomorphology became more natural relative to the original meadow conditions, and microbial and macroinvertebrate communities began to resemble forested streams rather than meadow streams. At the same time, the data collected also measured climate change in this area – mean and maximum stream temperature has been increasing (even in forested reaches) since 1996, and extreme precipitation events have become more frequent. Thus, this long-term study demonstrated that the positive ecological changes associated with reforestation have occurred while the watershed was also experiencing climate change.
